jim's trucking

If you consider that there have been an average of 
 160,000 troops in the Iraq theater of operations 
 during the last 22 months, and a total of 2112 deaths, 
 that gives a firearm death rate of 60 per 100,000. 
 
 The rate in Washington D.C. is 80.6 per 100,000. 
 
 
 That means that you are about 25% more likely to be shot 
 and killed in our Nation's Capitol, which has some of 
 the strictest gun control laws in the nation, than you 
 are in Iraq. 
 
 Conclusion: We should immediately pull out of Washington.
Phunting
2112 military deaths. The civilian death count is probably about 15,000.
jim's trucking

2112 military deaths. The civilian death count is probably about 15,000.
I think the numbers are meant to compare the relative safety between living in Washington DC and being in the armed forces in Iraq. I'm well aware there have been too many civilian deaths. Can you verify that we killed them all?

 We know what they were meant to compare. Phunting's point, and I agree, is that this is completely misleading. And 15,000 is a pretty darn low estimate from what I've heard.
bmittking
If we're just counting army casualties in Iraq, how many armed forces have been killed in Washington DC?
daewoo

2112 military deaths. The civilian death count is probably about 15,000.

 
 Even Iraqibodycount shows more than double your 15,000 number, and that only accounts for deaths that were reproted bty more than 2 media sources (which most likely means that it is wildly optimistic).
Iuris

I would also like to point out that this was 2112 vicims from among 160000 men trained for war, working in teams, equipped with state of the art communication and other gear, and each armed with at least one firearm, constantly aware of a threat.
 
 In Washington, you're talking about civilians. Not 100% armed, not 100% trained, not 100% equipped,...
 
 P.S., anyone notice that the above situation is very close to the NRA dream world? Everyone with a gun, everyone trained with the gun, ...
daewoo

P.S., anyone notice that the above situation is very close to the NRA dream world? Everyone with a gun, everyone trained with the gun, ...

 
 And resisting the most powerful military on the planet.
Iuris

Er, sorry, I was talking about the US army. They all have guns, legally, and are trained in their use. The other guys have guns and on-the-job training...
 
 I'm not particularly thrilled by either.
thbarker

LET'S PAY ATTENTION TO THE MATH PROBLEM (without going into the all the logical fallacies, biases and cause and effect errors) IN THE "Thought for the Day".
 
 The real danger with articles like this one is that if the reader accepts information on face value and without a critical eye, then the reader will retain information in support their point-of-view or as a demonstration of the error in another's point-of-view without recognizing fallacies that may be hidden in the text or information. Therefore, the information will be thought of as "fact". 
 
 Not one of you, I believe, caught this critical error in the "Thought for the Day"
 
 Using the article's U.S. death total of 2,112, the correct mathematical operations will show the U.S. soldiers deaths in Iraq as 720 per 100,000 per year, not 60.
 
 Any critical reader should have noticed, given a total of 2,112 deaths, that the deaths per 100,000 U.S. soldiers must be between 500 and 1,000 deaths per 100,000 per year. 
 
 The "Thought for the Day" calculated the U.S. soldier deaths per 100,000 as follows: (2,112/1.6) divided by (22) months. This result yields the value of 60 deaths reported in the "Thought for the Day".
 
 But the reported 60 U.S. soldier deaths per 100,000 is per month not per year as with the D.C. statstics. To get the U.S. soldier deaths per 100,000 per year, you must multiply the 60 deaths per month times 12 months. The result is that you get 720 U.S. soldier deaths per 100,000 per YEAR. 
 
 So, the real comparison is 80.6 (mostly civilian) deaths in D.C. versus 720 U.S. soldier deaths in Iraq per 100,000 per year. Not the 60 versus 80.6 that the "Thought for the Day" misleads the reader into thinking is the case. 
 As you can see, this causes a string of tangential debates among readers without their first correcting the statistic. 
 
 So, the article should conclude that you are 893% more likely to get killed in Iraq than in D.C. 
 
 If too many citizens are persuaded by fallacious arguments and/or statements and their conclusions, we are doomed. It takes time, energy, research and analytical skills to have an effective political and social discourse. 
 
 It is estimated that 27,000-30,000 Iraqi civilians have been killed over the past two years. At least 11,000 Iraqi civilians have died due to terrorist and war in Baghdad versus 480 civilian deaths (including any law enforcement deaths) in two years in D.C. 
 
 re: http://www.iraqbodycount.org 
 re: http://www.disastercenter.com/crime/dccrime.htm

Your analysis is just as misleading as the OP. What the OP does not show is the clarification that there have been only 88 firearm deaths in Iraq.
 
 http://forums.officer.com/forums/archive/index.php/t-27738.html
 
 Actually both the OP and your analysis are flawed. The OP leaves out the crucial number (88) of FIREARM DEATHS.
 
 It's good you believe in scrutiny though.
